thread.title: Insurers race to merge after Obama’s reforms
thread.title_full: Insurers race to merge after Obama’s reforms

title: Insurers race to merge after Obama’s reforms
text:
Welcome to your preview of The Times Subscribe now Insurers race to merge after Obama’s reforms The Affordable Care Act gave millions of Americans access to health insurance Jacquelyn Martin/AP Katherine Griffiths Banking Editor   
Two of America’s biggest health insurers have embarked on a $48 billion merger, marking the second huge transaction in a month as the industry responds to reforms driven by President Obama. 
The acquisition by Anthem, based in Indianapolis, of Cigna, of Bloomfield, Connecticut, combines the second and fifth-largest health insurers measured by revenue. 
The deal comes shorftly after Aetna’s move to buy Humana for $34 billion and accelerates the consolidation among healthcare companies in the wake of the Affordable Care Act, which has increased access to insurance for Americans. 
The rationale is that larger insurers have the negotiating power to Subscribe now
